item.description: What if we could figure out exactly how the building blocks of life work and harness their power with the rigor and predictability of computer science?

item.title: Microsoft Brings AI to U.K. Gene-Therapy Firm
Microsoft moves into biological computing with Station B
item.description: I led a team to create and launch the Station B initiative at Microsoft Research, with the aim of developing a platform for programming biological systems.

item.title: Microsoft partners with biotech on ‘biological computing’ and cell DNA programming
item.description: Microsoft hopes its platform will improve lower the costs of viral vector production for gene therapies, and enable research into antibiotic-resistant colonies of bacteria.

item.title: Researchers build nanoscale distributed DNA computing systems from artificial protocells
item.description: I led a computational team using our Visual DSD language to help develop communicating DNA circuits encapsulated in synthetic protocells.

item.title: Station B: A platform that could help boost production of lifesaving biological therapies
item.description: In collaboration with Princeton University, Oxford Biomedica, and Synthace, Station B aims to help scientists more efficiently & predictably combat disease.

Visual DSD
item.description:
Visual DSD is a programming language and software tool for designing nucleic acid circuits.

Acknowledgements

  • Visual DSD was developed by the following people, in reverse order of joining the project: Carlo Spaccasassi, Rasmus Petersen, Kathryn Gray, Colin Gravill, Neil Dalchau, Filippo Polo, Simon Youssef, Matthew Lakin and Andrew Phillips.
  • Luca Cardelli assisted with the design of the DSD language and extensive testing of DSD. Erik Winfree and his group have provided valuable feedback on DSD, together with Georg Seelig and his group.
  • The core DSD language was developed in F#. It uses Dynamic Data Display for visualising simulation plots and Microsoft Automatic Graph Layout for visualising networks.

item.description: I was a co-editor and contributing author of the 2020 Science report, led by Stephen Emmott. According to Nature, "That report inspired this week’s focus on computing in Nature", including the cover.
